block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Indonesian Leader Sees Different Reality President Suharto of Indonesia faces some agonizing choices in responding to the snowballing movement against him. Yet one reason for the turmoil is that the perceptions that frame his decision-making are a world apart from those that invigorate his opponents.
INTERNATIONAL

Indonesian Leader Sees Different Reality President Suharto of Indonesia faces some agonizing choices in responding to the snowballing movement against him. Yet one reason for the turmoil is that the perceptions that frame his decision-making are a world apart from those that invigorate his opponents.
Mr. Suharto said he would reshuffle his Cabinet. But analysts said he must make deeper changes if he is to survive in office.

New Political Stance in India India's nuclear tests have forced it to reset its political as well as its philosophical compass -- turning a nation that had long preached the gospel of peace into an international pariah.

Clinton Finds Few Takers President Clinton kept up his criticism of India for its nuclear tests. But his yearned-for web of constraining international relationships appeared to be no match yet for competition among national interests.
The leaders of eight major countries, meeting in Britain, turned their attention to other issues, including international crime and helping the world's poorest countries.
Big Stakes in Russia Election A vote for governor in a Siberian region, in which a possible presidential candidate is likely to defeat the incumbent, has attracted big money and unholy alliances.
Break in Argentine Bombing Argentina said it was close to a breakthrough on two bombings of Jewish targets and that it had arrested eight Iranian residents.
NATIONAL

Rights of Patients A Big Election Issue Public anger over the state of managed care has burst into this year's election campaigns as a major issue, with Democrats and a few Republicans seizing on consumer complaints and calling for a sweeping ''patients' bill of rights.'' The candidates' assault on H.M.O.'s marks a striking shift in public sentiment from the time when the insurance industry and the Republican-controlled Congress beat back the President's sweeping effort to overhaul the health care system.

Microsoft Talks Collapse Settlement talks between Microsoft and state and Federal justice officials collapsed, apparently after its chairman, William H. Gates, ordered lawyers to withdraw earlier concessions, and Justice Department officials said that they intended to file a sweeping antitrust suit tomorrow.

Pilots Fighting Age Limit At a time when Americans are living longer than ever, the Federal Aviation Administration is still forcing airline pilots to retire at age 60. Tomorrow, the Supreme Court will announce whether it will hear the appeal of a group of pilots who say that the regulation violates the Federal law barring age discrimination.

Jury Gets Bribery Case A Houston jury has begun deliberations in the Federal trial of a lobbyist and several former and current City Council members, who are accused of bribery and conspiracy in connection with a development project. The defendants say they were victims of entrapment by zealous Government agents.
NEW YORK

Hazardous Sidewalk Fare Street corner food vendors deliver a sidewalk smorgasbord as varied as the city itself, but with their diverse fare, many vendors are serving up a heightened risk of sickness, according to safety experts, city health records and tests of sidewalk food. Roughly 40 percent of New York's vendors handle foods that can be hazardous, according to city figures.

Avoiding Teller Machines A sizable number of bank customers are refusing to transact their business through automated machines. At savings banks in New York City, 40 percent to 60 percent of customers still use passbooks.

Rift Among Democrats Deep fissures have emerged in the Democratic campaign against Gov. George E. Pataki's $1.5 billion in budget vetoes, with Democrats from conservative districts reluctant to attack a Republican governor who is popular among their constituents.
OBITUARIES
Television
Weather
